aimike002 wrote:
> 
> Now here's the problem , innovation number 7 is a duplicate of
> innovation number 5, even though the '5 to 4' link would translate to
> different phenotypes from the two genomes
> 
> No doubt I'm mising something elementary here, but would appreciate
> some clarification on how the innovation table is built up.

Mike,

It's a good question.

Whenever you go to add an innovation to your global innovation list, you 
need to first search to determine if that innovation already exists.  If 
it does exist, then you should simply reuse that innovation ID.  If it 
doesn't exist, then you create a new innovation ID.

How you store innovations so that you can do these searches quickly is 
up to you.  It may vary depending on your implementation language, 
programming paradigm, or personal preference.  Commonly, you might use a 
hash table (std::map<> in C++) or maintain an ordered list of 
innovations (thereby making a binary search possible).

Personally, in C++, I keep two innovation lists.  One is my global list, 
the other is the list of new innovations for the current generation.  It 
works something like this.

GetInnovationId
   Binary search global Innovation list - if found return id
   Linear search generation Innovation list - if found return id
   Add new id to generation Innovation list

At end of each Generation
   Copy generation Innovation list to global Innovation list
   Clear generation Innovation list
   Sort global Innovation list

In words..  Any new innovations, within a single generation, are 
maintained in an unsorted list.  At the end of each generation, that 
unsorted list is merged into the master sorted list.  The advantage of 
this scheme is that searching for Innovations remains very fast and 
storage remains O(n).  One disadvantage is that it's slightly more complex.

Hope that helps.

--Steve
